conbody.p: Of course, writing a whole function just to pass some numbers to our sum function seems a bit tedious. We could easily make the list an argument to the function:
conbody.codeblock: sum12 :: Monad m => [Int] -> Enumerator Int m Int sum12 nums (Continue k) = k $ Chunks nums sum12 _ step = returnI step
conbody.p: But now there's not even anything Int-specific in our function. We could easily generalize this to:
conbody.codeblock: genericSum12 :: Monad m => [a] -> Enumerator a m b genericSum12 nums (Continue k) = k $ Chunks nums genericSum12 _ step = returnI step
conbody.p: And in fact, enumerator comes built in with the enumList function which does this. enumList also takes an Integer argument to indicate the maximum number of elements to stick in a chunk. For example, we could write:
(That produces 465 if you're counting.) The first argument to enumList should never affect the result, though it may have some performance impact.
Data.Enumerator includes two other enumerators: enumEOF simply passes an EOF to the iteratee. concatEnums is slightly more interesting; it combines multiple enumerators together. For example:
conbody.codeblock: run_ (concatEnums [ enumList 1 [1..10] , enumList 1 [11..20] , enumList 1 [21..30] ] $$ sum6) >>= print
